review.title: Eliminating the Weakest Link: Making Manipulation Intractable?
review.abstract: Successive elimination of candidates is often a route to making manipulation intractable to compute. We prove that eliminating candidates does not necessarily increase the computational complexity of manipulation. However, for many voting rules used in practice, the computational complexity increases. For example, it is already known that it is NP-hard to compute how a single voter can manipulate the result of single transferable voting (the elimination version of plurality voting). We show here that it is NP-hard to compute how a single voter can manipulate the result of the elimination version of veto voting, of the closely related Coombs' rule, and of the elimination versions of a general class of scoring rules.

sections.heading: Introduction
sections.text: One such problem is that agents vote strategically and misreport their true preferences to improve the outcome for them. For example, in each round of a popular TV game show Barthel, players should vote on which other player to eliminate, and presenter Anne Robinson then tells the unfortunate player: "You're the weakest link, goodbye!" Players have an interesting strategic decision to make: on the one hand, they should vote to eliminate weak players (since weak players tend to reduce the size of the jackpot), on the other hand, they should vote to eliminate strong players (since the overall winner wins the last jackpot and all others go blank), and on the other hand, they should vote to eliminate weak players (since weak players tend to reduce the size of the jackpot).

sections.heading: Other Related Work
sections.text: Bag, Sabourian, and Winter (2009) proved that many successive selection rules, including successive (plural) elected candidates in the top cycle (and thus in line with Condorcet), require strategic voting. Contizer and Sandholm (2003) investigated the impact on the traceability of manipulating the addition of a first round of the Cup rule to an election rule. This first round eliminates half of the candidates and makes manipulation of several remaining election rules, including plurality and Borda, more difficult. Elkind and Lipmaa (2005) expanded this idea to include a general technique of combining two election rules. The first round is run over a certain number of rounds to eliminate some of the candidates before the second rule is applied to the remaining candidates. They proved that many such combinations of election rules are difficult to manipulate.

sections.heading: Conclusions
sections.text: In general, eliminating candidates does not necessarily increase the arithmetic complexity of manipulation. In fact, we have created an artificial electoral rule that actually reduces the arithmetic complexity. However, for many of the electoral rules used in practice, the arithmetic complexity increases. For example, NP was known to be difficult to calculate how a single voter can manipulate the outcome of STV (the elimination version of plurality voting), and Nanson's and Baldwin's rule (elimination versions of the Borda vote). In this paper, we have shown that it is NP difficult to calculate how an individual voter can manipulate the outcome of the elimination version of veto rules, the closely related Coombs rule, and the elimination versions of the general class of evaluation rules.
